intro.title: Stress Type Test
intro.desc: Burnout, Anxiety, Anger, Avoidance ‚Äî how do you react when you're under stress?

burnout.name: Burnout
burnout.subtitle: Worn out by excessive work and obligations
burnout.desc: You are the Burnout type ‚Äî someone who has pushed themselves relentlessly under the weight of responsibility and duty. Even when your energy is depleted, you feel guilty for resting, and things you once loved have started to feel meaningless. Burnout is not mere tiredness; it is a profound depletion of physical, emotional, and cognitive resources. If left unaddressed, it can develop into chronic depression or serious physical illness ‚Äî making self-care your highest priority right now.
warnings: Extreme fatigue that doesn't improve even after rest
Growing cynicism and emotional detachment from work and life
Cognitive paralysis ‚Äî difficulty focusing or making simple decisions
Physical symptoms: headaches, digestive issues, weakened immunity
strategies: Schedule 30 minutes of 'doing nothing' in your calendar every day
Set strict digital boundaries ‚Äî turn off work notifications after hours
Practice single-tasking: focus on one thing at a time, fully
Book at least one enjoyable hobby or activity per week, non-negotiably
Practice telling a trusted person honestly: 'I'm struggling'

anxiety.name: Anxiety
anxiety.subtitle: A constant cycle of worry and tension
anxiety.desc: You are the Anxiety type ‚Äî your mind is rarely quiet, cycling through worries large and small. You tend to imagine worst-case scenarios repeatedly, and these thoughts disrupt your sleep and make everyday activities difficult. Anxiety drains energy by locking you in the past or future, preventing you from enjoying the present. Chronic tension also affects the body, causing increased heart rate, muscle tightness, and digestive problems that can worsen into an anxiety disorder if ignored.
warnings: Unstoppable rumination ‚Äî worry thoughts that loop endlessly
Insomnia or poor sleep leading to chronic fatigue
Heightened sensitivity to others' opinions and social anxiety
Physical symptoms: headaches, stomach cramps, persistent muscle tension
strategies: Limit your 'worry time' to 15 minutes a day ‚Äî postpone all other worrying
Practice 4-7-8 breathing (inhale 4s ¬∑ hold 7s ¬∑ exhale 8s) three times daily
Write your worries down and sort them into 'controllable' vs. 'uncontrollable'
Try mindfulness meditation or progressive muscle relaxation to anchor in the present
Reduce caffeine and alcohol, and commit to a consistent sleep schedule

anger.name: Anger
anger.subtitle: Stress that erupts as intense anger
anger.desc: You are the Anger type ‚Äî when stress builds up, it explodes outward as intense, sometimes overwhelming anger. You are especially sensitive to injustice, and you often follow a cycle of suppressing feelings until they burst all at once. Anger is a natural emotion, but uncontrolled anger can damage important relationships and seriously affect your professional life. Beneath the anger often lie deeper feelings ‚Äî hurt, fear, or helplessness ‚Äî that are worth exploring.
warnings: Impulsive words or actions that damage close relationships
Intense guilt and self-loathing after an outburst
Reputation damage and escalating workplace conflicts
Physical toll: elevated blood pressure and increased cardiovascular risk
strategies: When anger rises, immediately remove yourself and apply the '10-second rule'
Keep an anger journal to identify which situations consistently trigger you
Practice progressive muscle relaxation: tense each muscle group 5 seconds, then release
Express feelings using 'I statements': 'I feel angry when...' instead of accusation
Use regular aerobic exercise as a healthy outlet for accumulated stress energy

avoidance.name: Avoidance
avoidance.subtitle: Retreating from problems rather than facing them
avoidance.desc: You are the Avoidance type ‚Äî when faced with stress, your instinct is to retreat, ignore, or escape rather than confront. You find temporary relief in scrolling, gaming, or staying busy, but unresolved problems stack up and eventually return as a larger crisis. Avoidance gives short-term emotional protection, yet long-term it erodes your self-confidence and deepens feelings of helplessness. Practising small acts of confrontation today can prevent a much bigger collapse tomorrow.
warnings: Unresolved problems accumulating until they erupt into crisis
Growing dependence on social media, gaming, or food as escape
Missed opportunities from chronic procrastination on important decisions
Declining self-confidence and learned helplessness ('it won't work anyway')
strategies: The '5-Minute Rule': commit to doing a scary task for just 5 minutes ‚Äî then see what happens
Break the avoided problem into the single smallest next action and do only that
Use an app to cap social media and gaming at one hour per day
Open up to a trusted friend and brainstorm solutions together
Vividly imagine the positive outcome of resolving the problem to boost motivation
